But that which is brought forward on the opposite side, Tleat God always accomplislzes the end which lte designs, admits of an easy solution. For we do not contend that God by his absolute will (which not only predetermines the ordination of means to an end, but also the infallible production of the end) intended actually to procure the salvation of each and every man through the death of Christ; but that he appointed, willed, and ordained that the death of his Son should be, and should be esteemed, a ransom of such a kind that it might be of- fered and applied to all men individually. And this God evidently accomplished. For all acknowledge, or ought to acknowledge, that Christ so suffered, and died, and was offered up for the sins of all men, that all together, with- out exception, might, through his death, by believing‚ ob- tain remissiori of sins and salvation.
